Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support to a group working on the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, a particle physics laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland. The LHC machine and ATLAS, a large particle detector facility, were built as basic science tools using funds from NSF and other agencies around the world. One of their primary objectives was to find the Higgs Boson, the last particle in the historically successful "Standard Model" (SM) that accounts for so much of the existence of, and forces between, known particles forming the matter in the universe. This effort has been successful. The next step in the experiments is to look for evidence for physics Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) that might, for instance, account for the presence of the mysterious "Dark Matter" that makes up so much of the mass of the universe. The LHC is currently in the midst of Run 2, at almost twice the energy explored earlier and with significantly increased event samples. It is possible that evidence for BSM physics could emerge at this higher energy and with the higher event statistics.

The investigators from the University of Washington are searching for the new BSM physics through two approaches. The first is through the study of pair production of Higgs Bosons, with each Boson decaying into b-quarks. This work emphasizes specialized analytical techniques for identifying b-quark decays and for background estimation. The second approach is a search for neutral long-lived particles that decay in the ATLAS detector volume far from the LHC interaction point, where the high-energy beams collide. This search uses custom triggers developed by the group to select decays displaced from the collision point and will search for long-lived neutral Higgs bosons as well as a broad range of other BSM phenomena.

The group supports a broader impact program through public dissemination of the results from ATLAS, with emphasis on training students from underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our model of sub-atomic physics – how the universe works, how matter interacts – works to an amazing degree. At the sub-atomic level, we’ve been testing the Standard Model with increasing degrees of accuracy since the 1960’s. We’ve seen every particle it predicts, culminating with the discovery of the Higgs in 2012. However, we know there are gaps – in particular, dark matter, is missing. It is a fascinating question how such a large piece can be missing and yet the SM is able to so accurately predict sub-atomic experimental results. That question drives our research at the University of Washington. We carry this work out at the world’s highest energy laboratory, CERN, where the Large Hadron Collider is located, on the ALTAS experiment.

This grant funded research into two extensions to the Standard Model: neutral long-lived particles in a Hidden Sector and a Higgs doublet model. Both extensions, as must any reasonable explanation for new phenomena, do not perturb the Standard Model too much: after all, most measurements we and others make are correct to many decimal places. The Hidden Sector does this by being “weakly” coupled with the Standard Model; that is, it does not interact very much. The Higgs doublet model adds particles and fields to the standard model, but in a way that leaves current results unmodified.

During the year that this grant was funding this research, significant progress was made on both fronts. Three recent publications encompass work done on this grant. The first, a di-Higgs result, looked for two Higgs particles decaying to two bottom quarks each. It increased the excluded mass range to 260-3000 GeV.

The searches for Hidden Sector long-lived particles had two publications that came out of the work funded by this grant. Long-lived searches look for particles that travel through part of our detector without leaving any energy deposits, and the energy deposits that finally do leave can look like noise. We published new results using the Calorimeter and Muon subdetectors of ATLAS, ruling out Long Lived particles in a greater range than before.

Keeping an experiment like ATLAS running requires a great deal of additional effort. Our group was involved in maintaining the detector, working on planned future upgrades to the detector, and software work for ATLAS during this grant period. The bulk of research funded by this grant was pre-COVID, so in addition to publications, we presented results and new ideas at various conferences.

We also produced a letter of intent for the MATHUSLA detector. MATHUSLA will sit on top of one of the LHC’s interaction points, at a distance of about 100 meters. The rock and earth between the interaction point and the detector will filter out almost all particles. Long-Lived particles of an appropriate long lifetime, however, will travel the distance to the detector and decay inside it – providing a very low background environment in which to search for ultra-long-lived particles. The detector is designed to search for particles as long lived as big-bang nucleosynthesis can accommodate (which occurred during for formation of our universe).
